Award.AwardTitle: The Socorro Magma Body: Surface Uplift History and Crustal Dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Socorro magma body, which was identified by geophysical methods, is one of the largest known magma bodies on Earth. It is a tabular body approximately 3,400 square kilometers in area and less than 150 m thick situated at about 19 km depth below Socorro, New Mexico, within the Rio Grande rift. The area has the highest rate of upper crustal seismicity in New Mexico, activity, which presumably is triggered by deformation and ascending hydrous fluids above the Socorro magma body. Leveling and InSAR studies indicate that the magma body causes surface uplift at rates of as much as 2.5 to 3 mm/yr. By mapping and dating surface features in this project, researchers from New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology can constrain the age and uplift history of the magma body. When coupled with numerical modeling, the results will improve understanding crustal growth, magma genesis, and stress changes during rifting. The project advances desired societal outcomes through full participation of women in STEM through support of an early career female PI, increased public scientific literacy and public engagement with science and technology through outreach efforts, improved well-being of individuals in society through better understanding of earthquake and volcanic hazards in New Mexico, development of a competitive STEM workforce through training of undergraduate and graduate students and support of an early career researcher.

The Socorro magma body affords a rare opportunity to study a mid-crustal magma body (most others are much shallower), to relate mid-crustal processes to surface deformation, to study the effects of a deep sill on extensional processes, and to study magmatic crustal growth in rifted crust. The overarching goal of this project is to determine the long-term history of the Socorro magma body through a combination of geomorphoological mapping, surface exposure dating, and geodynamic modeling. The project determines: (1) if the magma body has a history longer than about 1 ka; (2) episodicity and ages of inflation; (3) changes in the locus of surface deformation through time; (4) relationship between surface faulting and the magma body; and (5) geometry of uplift sources. Specifically, the research team maps and correlates terraces formed along the Rio Grande and its tributaries for use as strain markers. Socorro magma body-related and Quaternary fault-related surface deformation is distinguished based upon differences in expected tilt directions, length of tilting, and magnitude of tilting. Terrace correlation involves relative heights above streams, characteristics of terrace treads, deposits and straths, and soil analysis. Key, well-preserved terraces are dated using the 36Cl depth-profile method. Geodynamic modeling tests the geometry and dynamics of the active uplift source (inflation, thermal expansion, feeder source, contraction of crystallized magmas, etc.) by comparison with InSAR and GPS results, and guides interpretation of past episodes of Socorro magma body surface deformation revealed by the terrace analysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Socorro Magma Body (SMB) is the second largest known body of molten rock in Earth's subsurface. It is a thin, horizontal sheet, about 150 m thick, covering an area of ~3400 sq. km. at a depth of ~19 km beneath the central Rio Grande Rift. It has been known for decades that the magma body causes uplift of Earth's surface above it, but the history and reasons for this uplift are less well known. As such, it represents a volcanic hazard to central New Mexico. The SMB also causes individual earthquakes and clusters of small earthquakes above it, in the depth range of ~2-15 km. As such, it potentially could trigger a larger, destructive earthquake.

Abandoned river terraces and other geomorphic surfaces at different elevations above the Rio Grande and Rio Salado (a western tributary) were studied in detail and dated using cosmogenic isotopes. These results show that, apart from the current uplift event, there have been at least two others, one between ~800 and 26 thousand years ago and another between ~26 and 3 thousand years ago. These results show that the SMB is a relatively long-lived magma body that has caused repeated episodes of surface uplift.

Numerical geodynamic modeling was undertaken to understand how to distinguish surface uplift caused by inflation events (when new magma was added to the SMB) from uplift due to thermal expansion of the rocks surrounding and above the SMB. These show conclusively that ongoing uplift is due to ongoing inflation and that thermal expansion could only be discerned at the surface immediately after the onset of an inflation event, but would not be recorded in the river-terrace record.

Geodynamic modeling also shows how inflation of the SMB changes the stress field in Earth's crust above it. These changes are large enough to trigger slip on small faults, causing the observed earthquakes.

In 2012 there was a swarm of small earthquakes above the SMB, and it has been speculated that such swarms (which also occured earlier) are related to inflation of the SMB. This is confirmed by new, high-resolution GPS results that show that the uplift rate above the SMB increased in 2012, in accordance with modeling results.

Thus, inflation of the SMB on at least four different time scales has been proven: 100,000 years, 1000 years, 100 years and <10 years. These results suggest that there is a finite (but difficult to quantify) risk of a volcanic eruption from the SMB. If this happens, it may manifest as relatively nondestructive basalt flows, like occur regularly on Hawaii. However, if rising basalt magma hits shallow water there may be an explosive steam eruption, which would form a maar crater, that could be more destructive.

"Spin-off" results, from the better understanding of river terrace history along the Rio Grande obtained in this project, are of two types. The first supports a model that relates river terrace formation to the glacial cycle. The second allows better understanding of arid soil development rates based upon our better ages of terraces.

This project partially suported four faculty members at New Mexico Tech, including one early-career, femal geophysics professor. Four graduate students were trained in this project: two PhD students in Earth Science, an MS student in Geophysics and a MS-Teaching student (a 6th-grade teacher in Santa Fe, NM). The MST student developed 6th-grade Earth Science curriculum centered around the SMB and volcanoes. One undergraduate student was involved.
